Great points, Wesley.  You do a great job characterizing the situation.

As=
 for your last question on why there is not a top tier conference in
EAs, t=
hat is a serious problem in the community.  You mentioned
"Foundations on E=
As" but I think your meant "Foundations of Genetic
Algorithms" (FOGA), whic=
h indeed has a low acceptance rate.  But FOGA
is not the conference you're =
looking for unless your paper is
theoretical because FOGA is a theory confe=
rence.  For the rest of us,
there is no venue with a low acceptance rate.

=
The reason for this lack of a selective venue is historical and
complicated=
.  Many of the major figures in EA history had different
views about how a =
conference should be run and what its goals should
be than people in other =
areas of machine learning.  There was an
emphasis on inclusiveness and some=
 had the philosophy that the prism
of history, rather than a few reviewers,=
 should have the final say on
what paper is great or not great.

Unfortunat=
ely for those of us in academia, that philosophy is no help
to us (as you p=
oint out) when we are tying to get jobs or tenure,
where acceptance rates a=
re scrutinized.  It really needs to change,
and I believe it will, but it i=
s probably going to take a generational
change in leadership.  So unfortuna=
tely it could take a long time.

In the meantime, we can still submit to co=
nferences like AAAI and
ICML.  The only problem is that the barrier to entr=
y for EAs is higher
than for other areas because of their lack of mainstrea=
m acceptance in
machine learning.  So we have to first justify using an EA =
at all,
whereas another method like value-function RL can just start from t=
he
premise that it's a good idea to begin with.  Still, people have
succeed=
ed in getting into these conferences with EA-based work, and it
is seeping =
in more and more.

In fact, the floodgates could open if EAs really start t=
o have
significantly better results.  I believe that is possible because th=
e
emphasis on representation in EAs is going to lead to new domains
being a=
ccessible.  We will see.

Another historical factor is that in America, the=
 academic lineages
coming out of other areas of AI for whatever reason esta=
blished
themselves in the top departments before EAs became popular, which
=
means EAs are not well-represented in US computer science departments,
whic=
h is a self-perpetuating problem.  Interestingly, the situation is
somewhat=
 different in Europe than in the US.  In Europe, EAs are more
mainstream.  =
In the UK for example most faculties that have AI
researchers include EA re=
searchers.  There is just a different history
there.

ken
